body_html:
Hi @poxvoculi , @rmlarsen
I tested the code in scikit-learn and it works there. So random inputs are valid inputs

    import random
    import numpy as np
    from sklearn.mixture import GaussianMixture as GMM

    x = np.array([[random.random() for i in range(198)] for j in range(2384)])
    gmm = GMM(n_components=200)
    gmm.fit(x)
    
    Y = gmm.predict(x)

Also I have obeserved that the gmm.py file in master and r1.0 branch are 2 completely different files.
Even though tensorflow 1.0 release date was 15 Feb 2017, gmm.py in r1.0 branch does contain code prior to 11 Jan 2017 only. Some refactoring was done on 21 Jan 2017 and 2 Feb 2017. Maybe this is cause of the issue.

    Y = gmm.predict(x)

Also I have obeserved that the gmm.py file in master  and r1.0 branch are 2 completely different files.
Even though tensorflow 1.0 release date was 15 Feb 2017, gmm.py in r1.0 branch does contain code prior to 11 Jan 2017 only. Some refactoring was done on 21 Jan 2017 and 2 Feb 2017.  Maybe this is cause of the issue.
body:
Hi @poxvoculi , @rmlarsen 
I tested the code in scikit-learn and it works there. So random inputs are valid inputs
```
    import random
    import numpy as np
    from sklearn.mixture import GaussianMixture as GMM

    x = np.array([[random.random() for i in range(198)] for j in range(2384)])
    gmm = GMM(n_components=200)
    gmm.fit(x)
    
    Y = gmm.predict(x)
```

Also I have obeserved that the gmm.py file in [master ](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/contrib/factorization/python/ops/gmm.py) and [r1.0](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/r1.0/tensorflow/contrib/factorization/python/ops/gmm.py) branch are 2 completely different files. 
Even though tensorflow 1.0 release date was 15 Feb 2017, gmm.py in r1.0 branch does contain code prior to 11 Jan 2017 only. Some refactoring was done on 21 Jan 2017 and 2 Feb 2017.  Maybe this is cause of the issue.
